Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Surveying for a pathogenic chytrid fungus in Taiwanese amphibians

POR.DRECONTENT:
Survey of a pathogenic chytrid fungus in wild Taiwanese amphibians

Amphibians around the world are in crisis with nearly one-third of all species at risk of extinction. Historically, anthropogenic activity has greatly affected many amphibian populations, however, the most recent amphibian declines have occurred in protected and pristine areas far from human activity. These enigmatic declines have been associated with the emergence of a pathogenic fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) that causes the disease chytridiomycosis in amphibians. Since its discovery in 1999, this disease has been linked to the decline of over 200 species worldwide with Australia, Central America, Western North America, and Western Europe suffering the greatest Bd-related losses in amphibian biodiversity. In Asia, Bd has recently been reported in wild amphibians from China, South Korea, Japan, and Indonesia, although many areas are still in need in surveying. The presence of Bd in Taiwan has been largely unexplored. Our study focused on detecting presence or absence of Bd in wild Taiwanese amphibians. Using a non-invasive swabbing technique, we surveyed 258 individuals from 18 amphibian species for Bd throughout Taiwan and found an overall Bd prevalence of 8.1% (21/258). All individuals that tested positive for Bd had low-level infections indicating that none of the infected individuals were at risk of mortality. We also used the same swabbing method to look for Bd in museum specimens collected from 1981-2009 and found the earliest record of Bd in Taiwan from a specimen of R. sauteri collected in 1990. Our results indicate that Bd is relatively widespread in Taiwan both taxonomically and geographically, and has been present in Taiwanese amphibians since at least 1990. This represents the first report of the highly infectious and potentially lethal chytrid fungus (Bd) in wild Taiwanese amphibians and gives greater implication towards the conservation of Taiwan's unique amphibian fauna in the wake of spreading zoonotic diseases, such as Bd. 

This work was completed in collaboration with Dr. Alex Yu of National Taiwan University, Lin-Chun Fu of the Endemic Species Research Institute, Dr. Lucy Hou of National University of Tainan, Hui-Yun Tseng of the National Museum of Science, and Dr. Vance Vredenburg at San Francisco State University.
